Hi neuroscience student here! Swearing is typically more preserved in people with speech problems and even brain injury patients because its controlled by a different part of your brain than normal speech. Language is usually localized to the left hemisphere of the brain but emotional language (i.e. swearing) is controlled by both the left and the right hemispheres

I just started a job in the mental health care field, and one of the questions for the physical was if I had been hospitalized for psychiatric issues. Because my answer was yes (not like you can lie about that they can always figure it out) my physical was put on hold and I needed a note from my primary care doc saying I was mentally fit for the job. So it was a little more complicated and took longer than it would have had I not been bipolar, but it wasnt a huge issue.

I throw them on the wheel, kinda like Im making a bud vase but then round out the top making a small hole. I also leave the bottoms thick so I can carve it to a rounded shape. When I take it off the wheel I use my thumb to press in one side to make the bowl part. When its leather hard I use a needle tool to make the holes, and carve it to the desired shape. 

When it comes to glazing I use a very small amount of wax on all of the holes, and then after glazing I scrape any glaze that gets into the holes out with a needle tool.

I think this is more likely to be x inactivation rather than chimerism: 
https://simple.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mosaic_(genetics)
I think its more likely to be an example of x inactivation, but if its a male cat definitely could be a chimera!

Its called a mosaic in genetics, caused by a few different things but most commonly X chromosome inactivation. It is often easily observable in cats cats because genes determining fur color are on the X chromosome. This only happens to females because of the pattern of X chromosome silencing. When the cat is developing the stem cells independently silence one X chromosome, resulting in some cells expressing the fathers and some expressing the mothers.

Genetic genie can use your raw data from 23 and me  to find snps and guides you through what they mean. That being said, take everything you see with a grain of salt because there isnt exact consensus on what every snp means in terms of protein function
Yeah Im not sure why deplin is such a high dose, it seems like for most people its excessive even with a mthfr mutation

Definitely dont get your hopes up too much, I had a similar situation where I thought folate was going to be the miracle cure but its way more complicated than that. I would suggest checking out Dr Ben Lynch (he has a ton of information on supplementation for specific SNPs - http://mthfr.net/ ). Also if your doc puts you on deplin definitely monitor how you handle it because it was initially way too much for me and caused some negative side effects. Ive found that over the counter supplements with folinate actually work better than an already methylated form for me, but everyone is different.
What lucky workmates!

Weekend trips are fun cause theres not as much stress if you forget something! 

Water purification
water bottles/hydration bladder 
Headlamp (check batteries before you go) 
Sleeping bag/pad
Stove (and fuel) 
Pot
Knife
Food
Shelter (tent/tarp) 
Rain gear 
Warm jacket and pants
Camp shoes (crocs, chacos, etc) 
Dry socks to sleep in 
Hat/gloves if its cold
Bear spray if youre in a bear prone area 
Med kit (with some things to treat cuts and blisters, tweezers, ibuprofen) 

One thing I like to do is wrap duct tape around my water bottle so I always have some handy

Oh and contractor trash bags work great for lining your backpack
Hey Im 22 too! Id suggest monitoring your memory externally somehow, such as journaling or talking to someone close to you because I had no idea how bad it really was until I stopped taking it.

Depakote made my memory absolutely terrible- to the point where I dont have any memories from when I was on it. I had to stop taking it because my blood levels got too high (even on the lowest dose) and my memory slowly came back. It sucks because I think it has been the most effective med Ive tried but I definitely wouldnt go on it again because of the memory issues

My randomly assigned freshman year roommate and I got along so well that we decided to live together a second year. She helped me through some of the hardest times in my life, and when I was in a mental hospital after a suicide attempt she was one of the few people who visited me despite her insanely busy pre med schedule. Saying goodbye to her was the only time I cried during graduation, and I miss her so much (although we do keep in touch)
